Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: The nursing assistant is assigned to a patient in critical condition whose vital signs must be monitored every few minutes.
Story: I stared at my phone, my stepmother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to your father.” My heart thudded. I knew how important this was—being asked to guide the family through the ritual, to show I belonged, to honor the traditions that had always felt just a little foreign to me. But as I stood in the hospital corridor, my pager buzzed urgently. Room 312. Mr. Harris. His blood pressure had been unstable all morning, and the doctor’s orders were clear: monitor his vitals every five minutes, no exceptions. My hands shook as I fumbled with my stethoscope, guilt gnawing at me. My family needed me to prove I was one of them, to step up and show respect. My patient needed me to be vigilant, to keep him safe. I felt split in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down, each demanding all of me at the same time.
